Expectation1: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation1: The site-wide evacuation alarm has just sounded, and you must stop everything and proceed to the muster point immediately.
Expectation2: Prepare sermons and deliver weekly messages during Shabbat services.
Situation2: It is time to begin brainstorming potential topics for a sermon several weeks from now.
Story: The shrill wail of the evacuation alarm slices through the clatter of hammers and drills. I drop my tools, heart pounding, and glance at my foreman, who’s already waving us toward the muster point. As a construction laborer, I know the drill—safety first, no exceptions, and the team depends on everyone following protocol. But as I jog across the gravel, my mind drifts to my other life. I’m a rabbi, and this is the only quiet moment I’ve had all week to begin shaping my next Shabbat sermon. The congregation expects inspiration, guidance, and I feel the weight of their anticipation. My phone buzzes in my pocket—a reminder to start brainstorming. I’m torn, caught between the urgent demands of the site and the sacred responsibility to my community. My boots crunch on the ground, and I wrestle with the impossible question: do I focus on the safety of my team, or do I seize this fleeting moment to serve my congregation?
